SGLT2.description: Reabsorbs glucose and sodium from the filtrate in the proximal convoluted tubule. Responsible for approximately 90% of glucose reabsorption in the kidney.

NHE3.description: Primary sodium-hydrogen antiporter in the proximal tubule. Exchanges intracellular H+ for extracellular Na+, playing a crucial role in sodium reabsorption and acid-base balance.

Chloride_Base_Exchanger.description: Anion exchanger that facilitates chloride reabsorption in exchange for intracellular base (typically bicarbonate or formate).

NBC1.description: Cotransporter that reabsorbs sodium and bicarbonate from the tubular fluid, essential for bicarbonate reclamation and acid-base homeostasis.

Amino_Acid_Transporters.description: Various sodium-coupled amino acid transporters that reabsorb amino acids from the filtrate. Multiple transporter subtypes handle different classes of amino acids.

Na_K_ATPase.description: Primary active transporter that maintains the sodium gradient essential for proximal tubule function. Pumps 3 sodium ions out and 2 potassium ions in per ATP hydrolyzed, creating the electrochemical gradient that drives secondary active transport.

GLUT2.description: Facilitated glucose transporter on the basolateral membrane that allows glucose to exit the cell into the blood after reabsorption from the apical side via SGLT2.

KCC.description: Electroneutral cotransporter that moves potassium and chloride together across the basolateral membrane, contributing to cell volume regulation and chloride reabsorption.

NBCe1.description: Basolateral transporter that moves bicarbonate and sodium from the cell into the blood. Critical for bicarbonate reabsorption and maintaining acid-base balance.

Protein_Channels.description: Basolateral transport mechanisms for moving amino acids and small peptides from the cell into the blood following their reabsorption from the tubular lumen.
